title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 20, 2019).

Purdue Pharma's signature OxyContin product notched billions of dollars in annual sales at its height, fueled in part by booming demand for high-dose pills.

Saudi Arabia is pulling out all the stops to give customers every drop of oil they've ordered, less than a week after the attack on its petroleum industry.

Stripe climbed closer to the top ranks of the highest-priced U.S. startups after a fundraising round valued the fintech firm at $35 billion.

Colt said it would stop producing semiautomatic rifles for civilians, citing a glut in the market.

A sudden spike in overnight lending rates is forcing the Fed to consider increasing its Treasury holdings for the first time in five years.

GM's parts suppliers are being forced to idle plants and lay off workers as a result of the UAW's strike against the car maker.

August was the strongest month for sales of previously owned homes in the U.S. in nearly a year and a half.

Amazon plans to buy 100,000 electric delivery trucks as it seeks to reduce its carbon emissions.

The Dow ended Thursday's session down 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq were essentially flat.

Airbnb said it expects to go public next year, the latest multibillion-dollar startup seeking to tap new capital.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 20, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
